rComments: Dine is a nice guy and he's brilliant! He really is quite a genius, but as such he's not used to teaching where he has to cover the basics... He's extremely vague and you have to piece together what he means on the homework (which he writes himself). The tests are just as complicated. Office hours, discussion sections, MAKE USE OF THEM.

Michael Dine is probably one of these easiest physics professors you could get for the 5 series. If you do bad on a test there is a large curve and also a 10% extra buffer you get for just participating in class. He is hard to understand and in the end I learned most of the material from the book.
Very chill guy that actually cares about students. However, his teaching is beyond terrible. He can't even do algebra correctly.
ok ok ok ok ok ok

Dine is really understanding w/ extensions on homework and keeps in mind that it's an intro class. HOWEVER, lectures are sometimes difficult to keep up with (despite the man being a genius), so the textbook is a must. I read ~90% of the recommended reading & came out of the class with a solid A. (A generous final curve probably helped too)

Professor Dine is very helpful with regard to replying emails and giving feebacks. His lectures are good reference to study, but the key to success in his class is not attending lectures but practicing the problems and asking quations. After all, he is very generous about giving points to those who work hard.

He is a really nice guy but his lectures are useless. You really don't have to attend class. Count how many times he says okay in one lecture. The book is necessary although it doesn't really help because his tests seem to be pulled out of his butt. Take some of the tutorials on line if you're struggling.

he looks like vizzini from the princess bride and has a lot of verbal static (count the times he says "okay" in a lecture seriously). however, he's funny, very clear, and amazingly understanding. i was unable to afford the book and he printed out the pages for me himself and graded my homework separately instead of online. he is a god.

Dine, though an expert in the field and on the material is useless in lecture.  Not only does he convey nothing, but he does that while dancing around unimportant topics... instead of even dancing around the myriad important concepts.

Michael Dine is awesome.  He is one of the most entertaining lecturers I've ever had.  He makes a lot of algebraic mistakes, but that's the only problem I've noticed with his lectures.  He's good at motivating definitions and problems before launching into explanations.  Plus, he looks kind of like a leprechaun on lots of caffeine, which is great.

Dine is a kind and enthusiastic person, but he shouldn't be teaching.  Not only are the proofs he does useless, he makes so many mistakes that he doesn't usualy finish them.  His homeworks are all over the map and his lectures are a waste of time.  If you learn well from the book, you'll do fine, otherwise be prepared for the biggest waste of time.

Dine doesn't skip any steps as he shows you his work. Which is great except that he always screws up the little details such as indices or minus signs. He has the energy to keep a 2 hour class entertaining, but since his math always has mistakes and he follows the book, lecture isn't necessary.
